Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Development of Polymer-grafted Lignin Superplasticizers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1510600
PI: Washburn, Newell R.

Hydraulic cement is a major contributor to global carbon dioxide emissions into the atmosphere. Low carbon dioxide cements are available but not widely used, because they are difficult to process. This project will develop a new superplasticizer that can be added to low-carbon dioxide hydraulic cement to improve the cement's processing characteristics while reducing carbon dioxide emissions. The new superplasticizer will be formulated using a process developed by the PI in which synthetic polymers are grafted onto lignin, a biopolymer derived from plants. Use of the new superplasticizer could reduce water use and improve the performance of low-carbon dioxide cements, both of which would reduce the environmental impact of construction.

The project will test the hypothesis that the complexity of lignin chemistry will enable the superplasticizer to adsorb onto a broad range of low-carbon dioxide cements. The project will identify chemistry-structure-property relationships governing the dispersant properties of polymer-grafted lignin in tuning the rheological properties of cementitious suspensions. The project will compare lignin chemistries and grafting variables to determine how they affect aqueous suspension properties, examine the adsorption of polymer-grafted lignin on cement particles as a function of grafting variables and charge, and establish effects of polymer-grafted lignin on the hydration of low-carbon dioxide cements and the formation of high-strength cement phases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lignin is a major coproduct from paper manufacturing but commonly finds use as a low-cost/low-performance additive in a diversity of applications. Its native function in plants is as a binder, and in the project, chemical strategies were explored for increasing its interfacial activities as a dispersant for concentrated cement suspensions. The strategies were focused on grafting anioninc polymers onto lignin nanoparticles. Commercial lignin sources tend to be enriched in carboxylate or sulfonate functional groups, with lignosulfonates being much more effective dispersants in aqueous media. However, grafting polymers with carboxylate functionality onto either type of lignin was found to result in highly effective dispersants for portland cement as well as blends of portland cement and minimally processed clays, which have lower embodied CO2. Grafting results in complex changes in the lignopolymer hybrids on both the solution properties and the particle properties in these suspensions, both of which can improve the flow of cement paste. To model these competing physical effects, a machine learning algorithm was developed that embedded additional physical models and data to make predictions based on small numbers of samples. The intellectual merit of this research was the identification of synergistic interactions between the lignin cores and the polymer grafts as well as the development of a machine learning algorithm for model complex physical systems based on small datasets. The broader impacts of this project included extensive research experiences for both three undergraduate students (all female) and two graduate students (one male, one female). One chemistry undergraduate is now a reseach chemist at L'Oreal developing products based on concentrated suspensions, and one civil engineering undergraduate is now an NSF graduate fellow working on her PhD at the Georgia Institute of Technology. CMU has applied for a patent covering the hierarchical machine learning algorithm, and PI Washburn founded a startup company Ansatz AI that is exploring commercial applications of it with clients in chemicals/materials industries.


Last Modified: 02/09/2020
Modified by: Newell R Washburn

    Newell R Washburn
    Lingopolymer dispersants for sustainable cements
